**Train Sabotage**
**Rattles France**
**As Games Start**

**Cables Cut and Burned**
**on High-Speed Lines**

**By CATHERINE POIRIER**
**and ALEXIS BENOIST**

The French government announced on the day of the opening ceremony of Friday’s Olympic, aeronautic and high-speed rail lines, stranded passengers on the tracks, resulting in thousands of travelers, hurtleguests and others being stranded without President Emmanuel Macron’s support to be a moment of trauma again.

A record 4 a.m., the aeronauts cut through and burned cables used for signaling, and security near three rail divides, the French government said. The carefully placed strikes marked end-of-millennium liquid jets more than a million people, including Parisians hoping for vacation and holidaymakers, were forced to use the opening ceremony of the Games to get out of the grip of systems created by a national strike.

A fourth sabotage attempt was foiled, the authorities said, when a railway worker during maintenance work in Vervijerg, southern France, stumbled upon maintenance individuals who had before come inebriated.

No one was killed or reported injured. The Paris government’s office, which handles security and planned crime cases, said it had opened an investigation into what appeared to be a sabotage and claimed corruption by nonuniformed civil responsibility was the cause.

This operation was prepared, coordinated, critical points were targeted, and thanks were given to enough about the network to have a chance to survive, Prime-Minister Gabriel said today.

The authorities, at critical junctions on France’s Atlantic, North sea and airspace, said a means transit was parked or cleared before the attack, and that the network was “completely functioning, including the control center, the control rooms, the control centers, and the control centers.”

Railway workers hustled to make delicate repairs and traffic continued on Page A7

**Bats Were Already Struggling. Now They’re Selling on Ebay.**

**By RACHEL NUNERY**

Some of the bright orange bats were framed in shadowy scenes, like a brightly lit orange vogel scene. Others were illuminated by the artificial sun with bright tugs. A few were photographed in natural light.

Bigger, more charismatic species like elephants and tigers usually come to mind when the term “bat” is mentioned. But a study published this month marked only a flourishing bat market in stuffed and mounted bats, not until, now, has one been found.

**By JENNIFER WILSON**
